message_1: Consider the polynomial ring $k[x,y,z]$ where $k$ is a field of characteristic zero. Let $C$ be the affine algebraic curve $C=V(y^2-xz)$. Then, for any positive integer $n$, find the dimension of the group $H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n))$ where $\mathcal{O}_C(n)$ is the sheaf of regular functions on $C$ twisted by the line bundle $\mathcal{O}_C(n)$.
message_2:
To compute the dimension of the cohomology group $H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n))$, we will use the long exact sequence in cohomology associated to the short exact sequence of sheaves on $C$:

$$0 \to \mathcal{O}_C(-n) \to \mathcal{O}_C \to \mathcal{O}_C(n) \to 0$$

This sequence is obtained by tensoring the standard exact sequence of sheaves on $C$ with the line bundle $\mathcal{O}_C(n)$. The long exact sequence in cohomology associated to this short exact sequence is:

$$0 \to H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(-n)) \to H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C) \to H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) \to H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(-n)) \to H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C) \to H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) \to 0$$

Since $C$ is an affine curve, we have $H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C) = 0$. Moreover, for any positive integer $n$, we have $H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(-n)) = 0$ because there are no non-zero global sections of a negative line bundle on a projective curve. Thus, the long exact sequence simplifies to:

$$0 \to H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C) \to H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) \to H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(-n)) \to 0$$

Now, we can compute the dimensions of the relevant cohomology groups. Since $C$ is an affine curve, we have $H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C) = k$ and $\dim_k H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C) = 1$. To compute the dimension of $H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n))$, we note that the global sections of $\mathcal{O}_C(n)$ correspond to homogeneous polynomials of degree $n$ in $k[x,y,z]$ that vanish on $C$. Since $C$ is defined by the equation $y^2 - xz = 0$, a homogeneous polynomial $f(x,y,z)$ of degree $n$ vanishes on $C$ if and only if $f(x,y,z)$ is divisible by $y^2 - xz$. The space of such polynomials has dimension $(n+1)(n+2)/2 - (n-1)n/2 = n+1$. Thus, $\dim_k H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) = n+1$.

Now, we can compute the dimension of $H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n))$ using the long exact sequence:

$$\dim_k H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) = \dim_k H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n)) - \dim_k H^0(C, \mathcal{O}_C) = (n+1) - 1 = n$$

So, for any positive integer $n$, the dimension of the cohomology group $H^1(C, \mathcal{O}_C(n))$ is $n$.
